docs.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1994, a surgeon named J. Bruce Moseley found himself engaged in an elaborate form of make-believe. Moseley had 10 patients scheduled for an operation intended to relieve the arthritis pain in their knees. The patients were men -- most of them middle-aged, all former military guys -- and they weren't ready to consign themselves to the rocking chair yet. So they had decided to take a risk and volunteer for a study that must have sounded, when Moseley first told them about it, rather peculiar. All 10 would be wheeled into an operating room at the Houston Veterans Affairs Medical Center, draped, examined and anesthetized. All 10 would be dispatched to the recovery room and sent home from the hospital by the next morning equipped with crutches and a painkiller. But there the similarities ended. For while two of the men would undergo the standard arthroscopic surgery for their condition -- the scraping and rinsing of the knee joint -- and three would have the rinsing alone, five would have no recognized surgical procedure at all. Their surgery would be a placebo, an exercise in just pretend. Moseley would stab the placebo patients' knees three times with a scalpel -- to make it feel and look real, there had to be incisions and later, scars -- but that was it. And he couldn't break character. If he knew in advance which kind of surgery he was to perform, he might somehow give it away, so it wasn't until he entered the gleaming O.R., scrubbed and in his greens, that he opened an envelope telling him whether he was doing a real procedure or a fake one that time. Only the anesthetist and the nurse assisting him were in on the secret.
docs.abstract: Margaret Talbot article on the amazing healing power of placebo pills and surgery and the research into what is responsible for it; discusses calls for putting placebo effect to conscious use in clinical practice, with patients fully informed that that they are being treated with placebos; notes estimate that anywhere between 35 percent and 75 percent of patients benefit from taking a dummy pill in studies of new drugs and that the effect can go beyond subjective sensation of patients to produce actual physiological change; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: BRUCE JONES is holding forth in a small conference room in the John Hancock tower in downtown Boston, talking about new features of a product that receives a lot of negative comment from experts -- variable annuities. Among other benefits, the annuities may now offer guaranteed returns, even in market downturns, and money for nursing home care. ''We've worked at answering objections to the product,'' said Mr. Jones, who is in charge of variable annuities, a combination of mutual funds and insurance, at the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, ''and we've added features to address things that consumers worry about.''

headline.main: Reinventing the Variable Annuity, With More Bells and Whistles

docs.abstract: Variable annuity issuers are offering new features in response to criticism of products, combination of mutual funds and insurance; financial planners remain wary because fees average 50 percent more than those for comparable mutual funds (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Margaret Moran's parents died within six weeks of each other in 1975, her first concern was for her brother, Jimmy, developmentally disabled since birth. Ms. Moran was 30 and working in Boston as a book editor. Jimmy, four years older, was living in a group residence in Philadelphia. ''With our parents gone, I knew there was nothing to do but step in and take responsibility for him,'' she said. ''I didn't want to. But someone had to make sure he was well taken care of.''

headline.main: Facing Hard Choices As the Disabled Age

docs.lead_paragraph: Joaquin Lavin, the first conservative candidate with a chance to win Chile's presidency since Gen. Augusto Pinochet left power in 1990, has never managed anything larger than a neighborhood of 250,000 people on the east side of Santiago. The neighborhood, Las Condes, is a redoubt of mansions, soaring glassy banks, luxury high-rise apartments and a city hall decorated with prints celebrating the world of polo and golf -- hardly the usual testing ground for a candidate who wants to govern a complex country of nearly 16 million people.

headline.main: Chilean's Homespun Record Could Make Him President

docs.abstract: Joaquin Lavin, first conservative candidate with chance to win Chile's presidency since Gen Augusto Pinochet left power in 1990, has softened image of country's right wing, which still carries baggage of human rights abuses of Pinochet dictatorship; Lavin, mayor of Las Condes, is part of new wave of younger politicians who appear committed to overturning traditionally highly centralized power structures of Latin y America, parlaying local government success into capturing national attention, and even high office; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Setting aside the bitter sarcasm of their previous encounters, Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley today made direct appeals to farmers and senior citizens, two important voting segments in Iowa, in the first of their series of debates to be held in this state. Mr. Gore prodded Mr. Bradley on several Senate votes that Mr. Gore said had gone against the interest of agriculture, including those against ethanol, crop insurance and price supports for farmers. Perhaps most dramatically, Mr. Gore highlighted Mr. Bradley's vote against federal disaster relief for farmers by singling out Chris Peterson, a farmer in the audience, and describing the 1993 flooding of 300 of his 400 acres.

headline.main: Gore Attacks Bradley on Agriculture Votes and Medicare

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore and former Sen Bill Bradley hold first of series of debates in Iowa; Gore says Bradley cast several Senate votes that went against interest of agriculture, and he highlights Bradley's vote against federal disaster relief for farmers; Bradley says nation needs change in its agriculture policy; Gore faults Bradley for not offering proposal to bolster Medicare; says Bradley's plan to expand Medicare's coverage of prescription drugs would fall well short of helping low-income people; Bradley claims federal surplus will allow for establishment of universal health care and preservation of Medicare; photos (M)

byline.original: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE and JAMES DAO

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN questions surfaced about Senator John McCain's emotional stability, he put them to rest last month with a deluge of paper: 1,500 pages of medical records, going back to 1973. And that was the abridged version. Americans now know that, psychologically, Mr. McCain is a rock, in the opinion of his doctors. But they also now know about the mole on his shoulder, about his arthritis, hay fever and intestinal polyps, as well as the size of his prostate gland.

headline.main: The Nation: Medical Histories; For Candidates, Defining How Healthy Is Healthy Enough

docs.abstract: Sen John McCain joins ranks of other presidential candidates, this year and in years pasts, who have released their medical records; such releases are not required by law but are rather made under pressure from news media and political rivals; some people believe public interest demands that usual right to confidentiality be waived, but others question whether the public needs, wants or has a right to such information; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Since 12 Victorian gentlemen gathered for its first meeting on April 6, 1858, in the New York home of Augustus B. Sage, the American Numismatic Society has grown into a research institution with one of the finest collections in the world, holding nearly a million Greek, Roman, Islamic, Asian and medieval coins. But in recent years, thanks in part to its low profile and, some say, its distant site in upper Manhattan, the society has largely been forgotten by the public. Now a plan to reduce the society's annual deficit of nearly $1 million by offering buyouts to its five curators while at the same time spending most of its endowment on a new home downtown has set off a rebellion by a group of devoted members.

headline.main: Coin Society's Plans Upset Some Members

docs.abstract: American Numismatic Society is roiled by plan to move downtown and offer buyouts to its five curators, in order to reduce annual deficit and raise profile of collection now housed in upper Manhatan; protesters led by Prof James H Schwartz will ask board to freeze buyouts for year and reconsider spending $16 million to move downtown from neo-Classical villa at 155th Street and Broadway; photos; director Ute Wartenberg notes cuts in pay and opening times; society's collection, library and curatorial expertise are known around world (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ever since the day in 1983 when residents broached the idea of building a National Purple Heart Museum here, the museum has remained just that: an idea -- whose time came, went and kept on going, for 17 years. Despite an advisory panel that includes Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf and the actor James Garner, more than $1.2 million in state grants, and the support of Gov. John G. Rowland, the military museum today is little more than an aging set of computer-enhanced blueprints and an unfulfilled flight of fancy for an unknown town seeking a tourist lodestone.

headline.main: Museum Project Boasts Money And Big Names, But No Museum

docs.abstract: National Purple Heart Museum in Enfield, Conn, has remained idea whose time came, went and kept on going, for 17 years; despite advisory panel that includes Gen H Norman Schwarzkopf and actor James Garner, more than $1.2 million in state grants, and support of Gov John G Rowland, military museum is little more than aging set of computerized-enhanced blueprints and unfulfilled flight of fancy for unknown town seeking tourist lodestone; report by Connecticut attorney general's office offers detailed explanation of reasons; map (M)
